IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Dedicated to providing trained assistance dogs to people with disabilities in order to increase independence and self reliance, through educational and vocational programs.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Dedicated to providing trained assistance dogs to people with disabilities in order to increase independence and self reliance, through educational and vocational programs.
IRS990.Desc: Our Foundation: 1 Dog: 1 Client In FY 2017, we placed nine of our fully trained assistance dogs to serve clients with disabilities. Four of the dogs are working with individuals with PTSD: two are first responders who are suffering from PTSD from job-related events; the other two are Veterans who needed support following their service. The other five are working with kids and young adults with special needs. An additional three teams competed the Owner Self-Training program, which teaches people with disabilities to train their own dog to be their service dog. 1 Dog: Many People, Courthouse and Facility DogsCourthouse Facility Dogs work in child advocacy centers, Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) agencies and with judicial districts Special Victim Advocates to assist children, teens and adults during traumatic criminal justice proceedings. In FY 2017, we placed six Courthouse Facility Dogs serving judicial districts based in the following cities: one in Hobbs, NM; one in Roswell, NM; two in Albuquerque, NM; and one in Los Angeles, CA. Additionally, we placed the first-ever Courthouse Facility Dog to work in a Tribal Court setting, in Pojoaque, NM. In response to requests from Courthouse Facility Dog graduates for additional training services, ADW hosted a Courthouse Facility Dog Reunion in March 2017. This event drew ADW graduates from across the country to participate in a two day intensive that included topics such as New Tasks, Canine Fitness, Vicarious Trauma: Techniques for Self Care, Crisis Response Deployment, and more. Student Trainer ProgramsCore to our organization's mission and training methodology, ADW continues to operate the largest Assistance Dog Student Trainer program in the world. In FY 2017, we continued our weekly in-school Student Trainer programs, integrated into the educational curriculum, with our decades-long partners in Santa Fe at La Mariposa Montessori School and Desert Academy High School. Our After-School Student Trainer programs also continued to be held twice per week at full capacity as well, with youth ages 8-18 participating. Summer 2017 saw the fourth year of ADWs Summer Camp, a student trainer program where youth participate in a weekly, full day summer camp experience. Summer Camp remains so popular that many youth signed up for two, three, even four weeks of camp over the summer, and there was a waiting list of others interested. We also continued to offer a weekly Student Trainer program to the high school students of the KIVA program through Santa Fe Public Schools. KIVA, which stands for Keeping Independent Visions Alive, serves students ages 18-22 with developmental and intellectual disabilities, teaching them skills to increase their post-high school employability and independent living. We served 12 KIVA students through the 2017-18 school year. All of our Student Trainer programs and Summer Camps are inclusive to students with disabilities, and those without disabilities, as well. We are proud of the friendships and community inclusion that result. ADW provides scholarships to student trainers in need, making this enriching opportunity available for all members of our community. Over 150 youth in Santa Fe were served by our Student Trainer programs in FY 2017. New PartnershipsADW entered into new partnerships with two youth shelters: DreamTree Emergency Youth Shelter in Taos; and Youth Shelters and Family Services in Santa Fe. ADW travels weekly with our service dogs-in-training on site to provide an accessible and trauma-informed student trainer program to these youth in need. ADW Youth BoardADW offers the opportunity to exceptional Student Trainers to continue their leadership and volunteer service by serving as members of our Youth Board. Our FY 2017 Youth Board was made up of eight youth ages 11-17 years old. They each demonstrated commitment and passion to furthering ADWs mission through their organization and implementation of public outreach and education at events, fairs, and community businesses and organizations. The Youth Board is led by our Executive Director and Instructor/Trainer, Linda Milanesi, who instills work ethic and leadership skills in the Youth Board members. Many of our Youth Board members serve throughout their middle and high school years, and maintain close contact with ADW throughout their college careers. Our longtime Youth Board President, Natalie Longmire-Kulis, was granted early admission to Stanford University, in part due to her stellar community service with ADW, including being a catalyst for starting our Teen Court program. The Warrior Canine Connection In FY 2017, we continued our Warrior Canine Connection programs in Albuquerque, rural Taos, NM, and also at our headquarters in Santa Fe. The program engages Service Members with Post-Traumatic Stress (PTS), Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI), and other challenges with reintegrating to civilian life, in training service dogs to be placed with other Veterans with disabilities. Our WCC program began in 2014 in partnership with Veterans Court, serving justice-involved veterans; we have now opened the programs in all three northern New Mexico locations to include all veterans, whether justice-involved or not. To date, over 58 veterans have been served by our WCC program, in addition to the three veterans per year with whom we place fully-trained assistance dogs to mitigate their own disabilities. These veteran placements are free of charge to the veteran, including mileage, lodging and per diem for placement, through a grant with the Department of Defense, received annually since 2015. We have placed 9 assistance dogs with veterans through this program, and are contracted for an additional 3 placements in the coming federal fiscal year. Our WCC program in Taos will re-launch in September, 2018, in partnership with VetCorps, an AmeriCorps national community service program. The first of such programs in NM, VetCorps engages Veterans and Military Family Members in agricultural community service to not only feed the local community, but support Veterans in transitioning to civilian life. VetCorps members participate in ADW-Taos Warrior Canine Connection program as additional service to the community, and as personal development/rehabilitation. Programs at our Rural Satellite in Taos, NMADW continued its various Student Trainer programs at our rural satellite office in Taos, about 1.5 hours north of Santa Fe. ADW-Taos has a beautiful new office space and there are now 5 pups in-training living in Taos full-time! They are being trained through student trainer programs happening now every day in Taos, including the inaugural Canine-Assisted Leadership Crew, a partnership between ADW, Rocky Mountain Youth Corps, and the NM Division of Vocational Rehabilitation. Eight local youth, ages 16-19 years old, will be hired in September to this 10-month, paid crew to help train the service dogs, while learning generalizable job, life, and disability inclusion and self-advocacy skills. We also continue our weekly therapeutic student trainer programs at local domestic shelter, Community Against Violence. We thank all our adult, teen, and child student trainers in Taos that help us train over 75 student trainers in 2018 thus far!Puppy Enrichment Center at Sunrise Springs and Volunteer CoordinationADWs Puppy Enrichment Center, located at the Sunrise Springs Spa in Santa Fe, continues to be the peaceful site where ADW whelps and raises our purpose-bred assistance dog puppies, while providing cognitive, social, and emotional activities to prepare them for service work. Sunrise Springs is a residential spa, where guests can participate in healthy activities such as yoga, mindfulness instruction, gardening, and more. Guests can participate in puppy enrichment activities, led by our on-site Puppy Enrichment Supervisor. Two litters of ADW puppies spent their first days and months at the Puppy Enrichment Center in FY 2017, where the foundation is set for their future service work. Longtime ADW volunteer, Susan Rivenbark, continues as our Volunteer Coordinator, and is instrumental in taking on the development of the role and organizing and managing our corps of volunteers, which includes our Puppy Sitters at the Puppy Enrichment Center and our weekend Puppy Raisers, as well as special events and graduation volunteers. Through her work, ADW now has an efficient process for recruiting, training, managing, and communicating with our volunteers. Community Outreach and EducationADW partnered with the New Mexico Coalition Against Domestic Violence to assist their 38 member domestic violence shelters and programs located throughout the state in understanding their rights and responsibilities regarding supporting survivors with service animals and emotional support animals. With a special emphasis on inclusion and safety for the survivor and their animals, including pets, we created a Model Guidelines document, short video, recorded we

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part V, Line 4: Intended uses of the endowment fund.
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The purpose of the fund is for the Foundation to make grants to the Donor.
The organization believes that it has appropriate support for income tax positions taken. Therefore, management has not identified any uncertain income tax positions.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule L, Part V Supplemental Information
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Assistance Dogs of the West leases property indirectly owned by the organization's founder/employee and member of the board of directors.

Client Note 1 - Schedule O, Program Service Accomplishments, ContinuedWCC Data Evaluation (continued)Working with Senior Evaluator Curt Mearns, PhD, and Research Assistant Denise Garcia, M.S., we redesigned our program evaluation process, forms, and reporting for Warrior Canine Connection. We are currently using this new process and will receive an initial report in September, 2018. Strategic Planning ProcessADW continues its strategic planning process to develop long-term organizational goals and succession plan. During FY 2017, we continued to meet in sub-groups as developed during the original retreat in FY 2016. Using the Open Space modality, this work is focused on gathering the input of staff, volunteers, clients, and Board Members as we move forward.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b: Form 990 Review Process
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Form 990 is e-mailed to all board members for review. Their approval of the 990 is sent to the Executive Director via e-mail prior to filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c: Explanation of Monitoring and Enforcement of Conflicts
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Each board member of the organization is asked to sign the Conflict of Interest Questionnaire each fiscal year. The board is presented the written disclosure of any board member involved in annual transactions with the organization that exceed $5,000.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15a: Compensation Review & Approval Process - CEO, Top Management
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Assistance Dogs of the West board of directors determines the appropriate compensation by assessing compensation for similar job or deliverables in the Santa Fe and Albuquerque, NM area. Such deliberations are documented in the board of director minutes.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15b: Compensation Review and Approval Process for Officers and Key Employees
Form 990, Part VI, Line 19: Other Organization Documents Publicly Available
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Such documents are available upon request.
